title: Letter: Now, about that Spartan nickname
content: I recently found myself pondering the mascot for , the Spartans. In the current movement to choose mascots more appropriate for modern times, I said the word “Spartans” aloud and started laughing immediately.  Who were the Spartans, other than those muscled naked-ish men who fought off 7 quadrillion Persians at the Battle of Thermopylae in the film "300?"  Sparta was a nation completely devoted to breeding for war, training for war, and engaging in war. When a child was born, s/he was taken immediately to a council (not counsel) of elders who decided if the child would be a good soldier or good breeder. If not, the child was set out on a hill to die from exposure (the historian Plutarch said they were thrown from a cliff).   Little boys were removed from their parents at age 7 to begin a lifelong career as a warrior. They were brutalized, starved, bullied, killed, and otherwise shaped into the perfect soldier. Homosexuality was encouraged so that they would go into battle not only a band of brothers, but also as soldiers who often fought side by side with someone they loved.   Girls had the primary duty of breeding the perfect warrior babies, not always with their husbands.  Are these the values espoused by 509J and the leaders at ? Infanticide, bullying, war, breeding programs? After all, that’s who the Spartans were.  Personally, I think the mascot for Linus Pauling Middle School should be the Ascorbic Acids. Corvallis (June 2)
